title: DF4 Kinetics - 1st order - N2 vs F2 PE diagram

content.question: Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. An unknown gas, <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, reacts with fluorine gas to form the compound <math alttext="D F 4, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>D</mtext><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, as represented by the following equation. <math alttext="D, gas, plus 2 F 2, gas, react to produce D F 4, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>D</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>→</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>DF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> A series of experimental trials were performed at <math alttext="600 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>600</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>∘</mo></mrow></msup><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math> to determine the rate law expression for the reaction. Data from the trials are shown below. Initial <math alttext="P sub D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="in torr" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>torr</mtext></mrow></math>) Initial <math alttext="P sub F 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><msub><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="in torr" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>torr</mtext></mrow></math>) Initial Rate of Appearance of <math alttext="D F 4, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>D</mtext><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="in torr per minute" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>torr/min</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) Trial 1 3000 3000 <math alttext="2.50 times 10 to the negative 2 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>2.50</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> Trial 2 6000 3000 <math alttext="5.00 times 10 to the negative 2 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="bold"><mrow><mstyle alttext="10.0 times 10 to the negative 2 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>10.0</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> (a) A student claims that the reaction is first order with respect to <math alttext="D, gas" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>D</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>. Do you agree or disagree? Justify your answer using the data above.

frqParts.text: Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. An unknown gas, <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, reacts with fluorine gas to form the compound <math alttext="D F 4, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>D</mtext><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, as represented by the following equation. <math alttext="D, gas, plus 2 F 2, gas, react to produce D F 4, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>D</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>→</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>DF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> A series of experimental trials were performed at <math alttext="600 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>600</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>∘</mo></mrow></msup><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math> to determine the rate law expression for the reaction. Data from the trials are shown below. Initial <math alttext="P sub D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="in torr" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>torr</mtext></mrow></math>) Initial <math alttext="P sub F 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><msub><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="in torr" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>torr</mtext></mrow></math>) Initial Rate of Appearance of <math alttext="D F 4, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>D</mtext><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="in torr per minute" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>torr/min</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) Trial 1 3000 3000 <math alttext="2.50 times 10 to the negative 2 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>2.50</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> Trial 2 6000 3000 <math alttext="5.00 times 10 to the negative 2 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="bold"><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>5.00</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> Trial 3 3000 6000 <math alttext="10.0 times 10 to the negative 2 " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>10.0</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> (a) A student claims that the reaction is first order with respect to <math alttext="D, gas" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>D</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>. Do you agree or disagree? Justify your answer using the data above.

(b) What is the initial rate of disappearance of <math alttext="F 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> in trial 1? Justify your answer.

(c) A student claims that if element <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is in group 18, then the molecular geometry of <math alttext="D F 4, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>D</mtext><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is tetrahedral. Do you agree or disagree with the student? Justify your answer in terms of <math alttext="V S E P R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>VSEPR</mtext></mrow></math> theory.

The particulate model shown below represents the moles of particles present in the container after <math alttext="D, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>D</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> have reacted in a different experiment. Assume that each particle in the diagram represents one mole of the respective substance. (Note: The box corresponding to “Before Reaction” is intentionally left blank.) (d) If the total pressure at the end of the reaction is <math alttext="12 atmospheres" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>12</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>a</mtext><mtext>t</mtext><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, what is the partial pressure of <math alttext="D F 4, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>D</mtext><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>?

(e) Assuming that only <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></math> and <math alttext="F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> are present in the container before the reaction, determine the number of moles of <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> that were present in the initial reaction mixture.<math alttext="D equals blank. F 2 equals blank." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnalign="left" rowalign="center" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="3.0em"></mspace><mtext>D =</mtext><mtext> __________</mtext></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="3.0em"></mspace><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo>=</mo><mtext>__________</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

The equation and enthalpy change for the reaction between <math alttext="D, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>D</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> are given below.<math alttext="D gas, plus 2 F 2 gas, react to produce D F 4 gas. Delta H naught equals, negative 250 kilojoules per mole of reaction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>D</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>→</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>D</mtext><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msup><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mo>∘</mo></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>250</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>kJ</mtext><mtext>/</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>mo</mtext><mtext>l</mtext></mrow><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></mstyle></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>(f) How much heat is released when <math alttext="4.0 moles" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>4.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext> m</mtext><mtext>o</mtext><mtext>l</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="F 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mi>g</mi></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> reacts with excess <math alttext="D, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>D</mi><mo>(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mi>g</mi></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>?

Fluorine can also react with another gas, <math alttext="E, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, according to the following equation.<math alttext="E gas, plus 2 F 2 gas, react to produce E F 4 gas. Delta H naught equals negative 350 kilojoules per mole of reaction." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>E</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>→</mo><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>E</mtext><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msup><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>∘</mo></mrow></msup><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>350</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>kJ</mtext><mtext>/</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>mo</mtext><mtext>l</mtext></mrow><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>(g) The student claims that the <math alttext="D F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>D</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> bond energy is greater than the <math alttext="E F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>E</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>F</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> bond energy. Do you agree or disagree? Justify your answer.

While investigating the properties of other diatomic molecules, the student finds the diagram below, which shows the potential energy of two nitrogen atoms versus the distance between their nuclei. The student incorrectly sketches the potential energy curve for two fluorine atoms, shown by the dotted line in the diagram. (h) Explain the error with the student’s sketch for <math alttext="F 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 1.A: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate particulate-level properties only.
